items.item_details:
Item:  9.01
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:30 p.m. on a Charter School Renewal Submitted by Latino College Preparatory Academy
	 
BACKGROUND
	 
Public Charter Schools are approved initially for up to a five (5) year period and at the end of that time must apply for a charter school renewal for a term of five (5) years and continue to apply for renewal after each five (5) year term. Pursuant to Education Code 47605 a public hearing is required within thirty (30) days following the submission of a renewal charter school petition to the district.  The renewal petition was submitted to the district on January 3, 2011.  When requested by the district, an extension of the thirty (30) day requirement for a public hearing may be granted by the petitioning charter school entity.  Such permission was granted by the petitioner, Latino College Preparatory Academy. 
	 
During the Public Hearing the Governing Board of the school district shall consider the level of support for the petition by the teachers employed by the district, other employees of the district and parents.  The Governing Board shall either grant or deny the charter renewal within sixty (60) days of receipt of the petition; however, the date may be extended by an additional thirty (30) days if both parties agree to the extension.  Such agreement has been reached and at the March 24, 2011 Board Meeting the Governing Board shall make its determination.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE: 
Part of Review Process
	 
FISCAL IMPACT: 
Part of Review Process
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Hold Public Hearing to consider level of support for the petition renewal submitted by Latino College Preparatory Academy.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.03
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Impact of Governor's Proposed State Budget Plan
	 
	 
The Governor’s 2011 Budget proposal of January 10, 2011, represents a significant turnaround from the previous administration’s approach to K-12 funding.  The Governor acknowledges that K-12 has borne more than its fair share of budget cuts over the past few years.  The Governor’s Budget proposal seeks to protect K-12 funding by sparing education from 2010-11 mid-year cuts and by offering a glimmer of hope with a flat budget for 2011-12.  Governor Brown is working diligently to place this issue before the voters in June 2011.
	 
Governor Brown proposes to close an estimated $26 billion budget gap in 2011-12 by:
by reducing $12.5 billion from health, social services and higher education; and 
by asking California voters to approve, on the June 2011 ballot, a five-year extension of various taxes, estimated at nearly $9 billion (both taxes are set to expire this year).
	 
Santa Clara County school districts must submit their Second Interim Budget Report to the Santa Clara County Office of Education by March 15, 2011, built on the assumptions presented by the Governor’s Budget.  Given this parameter, East Side Union High School District must plan for the worst case scenario.   The worst case scenario occurs if the voters reject the June initiative.  In our situation, it means preparing a budget that includes a reduction in the revenue limit of $7.7 million, plus other expenses, for a total estimated reduction of nearly $12.5 million for 2011-12.

items.item_details:
Board Meeting of February 17, 2011
Item:  9.04
	 
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Support Placing a Revenue Extension Measure on the Ballot
Resolution #2010/2011-24
	 
	 
WHEREAS, Governor Brown’s 2011-12 budget proposal is a balanced approach between revenues and new cuts to solving the deficit and provides for an extension of temporary revenues to support programs our students need and deserve; and 
	 
WHEREAS, over the last several years, K-12 education funding has taken a disproportionate amount of budget cuts; and 
	 
WHEREAS, state and local funding for schools has been cut by more than $18 billion, or about $1,900 per student in the last three years; and
	 
WHEREAS, East Side Union High School District has cut $83,243,081 from its budget over the past three years as a result of ongoing statewide cuts to education funding; and
	 
WHEREAS, the loss of $7 billion in one-time federal funding further reduces school budgets; and
	 
WHEREAS, to begin to reverse this downward spiral, Californians must retain the revenues that enable us to invest in our schools and students; and
	 
WHEREAS, the Governor’s budget proposal to limit further cuts to schools in 2011-12 is dependent on voter approval of an extension of existing temporary tax increases; and 
	 
WHEREAS, a ballot measure to extend temporary revenues will help prevent further cuts to schools, and without this extension the LAO reports that funding for schools would fall by at least $2 billion, or more than $335 per student; and
	 
WHEREAS, East Side Union High School District expects our local legislators to work with the Governor to protect schools from further cuts and to ensure the continued investment our students deserve; and
	 
WHEREAS, East Side Union High School District opposes a cuts-only budget and supports a budget that is balanced with a combination of cuts and revenue extensions;
	 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED that the East Side Union High School District supports placing a measure on the June 2011 ballot calling for a five-year revenue extension to protect our schools and students by making education a priority in our state.
	 
PASSED AND ADOPTED this 17th day of February, 2011 by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its Regular Meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California.
	AYES: ________
	NOES: ________
	ABSENT: ______
	ABSTAIN: ______
	I certify the foregoing resolution was duly introduced, passed, and adopted by the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees at a meeting held on February 17, 2011.
	_________________________
	Clerk
	ESUHSD Board of Trustees

SUBJECT:
Opening of Sealed Proposals Received by District for Proposed Cellular and Wireless Communication Antenna Sites at District Facilities per Board Resolution #2010/2011-18
	 
	 
At the November 18, 2010, Regular Board Meeting the Board approved by two-thirds majority vote Resolution 2010/2011-18 (the “Resolution”) declaring the District’s intention to lease certain District property for installation of cellular and wireless communication antenna.  Notice of the Resolution was published and posted as required by law. The Resolution and the published and posted Notice of Intention to Lease specified that the District would receive sealed proposals to lease from interested parties up to 5:00 p.m. on February 16, 2011. The Resolution further specified that the sealed proposals would be opened the next day at the time of the Board’s February 17 meeting. Pursuant to Education Code sections 17472 and 17473, all sealed proposals received by the District in accordance with the Resolution and the Notice of Intention to Lease shall be opened, examined and declared by the Board in public session. Before accepting the sealed proposals, the Board shall call for oral bids upon the terms outlined in Section 17473.
At the time of the February 17, 2011, meeting, Administration will present to the Board all sealed proposals received by the District in accordance with the Resolution and the Notice of Intention to Lease. 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Lease - Revenue to be Determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees open, examine and declare all sealed proposals to lease received by the District in accordance with the Resolution and the Notice of Intention to Lease.

Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students
	 
DESCRIPTION:  
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student's parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CASHEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CASHEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students' parents.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  10.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Tim Nguyen, Coordinator of English Language Learners Supplementary Education
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve 2011 Summer School Program
	 
	 
The twenty-day Summer School Program which begins on June 16, 2011 and ends July 14, 2011 (no school on Monday, July 4th), will be available for incoming 9th grade students, our Special Needs students at risk of failing the High School Exit Exam (CAHSEE) and for eligible students in Special Education.
	 
The estimated reimbursement from the State is based on 81.6 percent of the 2007-08 funding for Supplemental Instruction.  Additionally, the Supplemental Instruction fund is part of the Tier III Categorical Program, which allows the fund to be "swept" to help augment the general fund and to allow for greater flexibility in its use by districts.
	 
A description of the summer school programs are described below:
	 
1.  At-Risk incoming 9th graders
The goals of the 9th grade summer programs are to prepare students who are not demonstrating sufficient progress towards passing the CAHSEE for success in Algebra 1 and English 1, articulate with feeder school teachers about student achievement and curriculum focused on CAHSEE standards, and to provide professional development on best practices relating to teaching strategies and curriculum designed to prepare students for rigor of high school.
	 
2.  Special Education
Special Education classes will be offered at WCO, AH, JL, and YB High Schools for Special Day Class (SDC) students who qualify for Extended School Year (ESY) Services per their IEP. Funding for the SDC students is provided through a daily allocation from the State Department.
	 
Summer School Sites:
The following school sites are being recommended as locations for summer school during the summer of 2011:
Andrew Hill High School                
Independence High School           
James Lick High School
Mt. Pleasant High School
OakGrove High School       
W.C. Overfelt High School
Yerba Buena High School       
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
Summer School Bell Schedule:
	 
Period 1     7:50  a.m.   -  10:10 a.m. (140 min.)
“B” Period  10:10 a.m.  -  10:35 a.m. (20 min.)
Period 2     10:40 a.m.  -  1:00   p.m. (140 min.)
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT
$500,000* (estimated)

Item:  12.01
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Business Services Division
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Award/Acceptance of Proposals to Lease District Sites for Cellular and Wireless Communication Antenna Purposes per Board Resolution #2010/2011-18
	 
	 
At the November 18, 2010, Regular Board Meeting, the Board approved by two-thirds majority vote Resolution 2010/2011-18 (the “Resolution”) declaring the District’s intention to lease certain District property for installation of cellular and wireless communication antenna. Notice of the Resolution was published and posted as required by law. The Resolution and the published and posted Notice of Intention to Lease specified that the District would receive sealed proposals to lease from interested parties up to 5:00 p.m. on February 16, 2011. The Resolution further specified that the sealed proposals would be opened the next day at the time of the Board’s February 17 meeting.  Pursuant to Education Code sections 17472 and 17473, all sealed proposals received by the District in accordance with the Resolution and the Notice of Intention to Lease shall be opened, examined and declared by the Board in public session. Before accepting the sealed proposals, the Board shall call for oral bids upon the terms outlined in Section 17473.
At the time of the February 17, Board meeting, Administration will present to the Board all sealed proposals received by the District in accordance with the Resolution and the Notice of Intention to Lease.
Pursuant to Education Code section 17529, a school district may enter into a lease agreement for the joint use of operating school sites provided the Board first determines that the joint occupancy/use of such property will not: (1) interfere with the education program or activities of any school or class conducted upon the real property or in any building; (2) unduly disrupt the residents in the surrounding neighborhood; and (3) jeopardize the safety of the children of the school. At the September 17, 2009, Regular Board Meeting, the Board held a public hearing to solicit community input on the potential leasing of District property for such purposes. 
At the time of the February 17 meeting, and per the earlier agenda item for the opening of sealed proposals, the Board will open all sealed proposals received by the District. Once opened, the proposals will be reviewed by staff and a recommendation made to the Board. Final acceptance of the Board may be made by majority vote at the time of the February 17 meeting (provided the Board first makes the determinations set forth in the preceding paragraph). Alternatively, the Board may reject any and all received bids (either written or oral) and withdraw the property from lease if it deems such action to be for the best public interest. (Education Code section 17476).   
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Lease - Revenue to be Determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that all sealed proposals to lease received by the District in accordance with the Resolution and the Notice of Intention to Lease be reviewed by staff.
Administration recommends that the Board find that the joint occupancy/use of District as proposed in the Resolution will not: (1) Interfere with the education program or activities of any school or class conducted upon the real property or in any building; (2) unduly disrupt the residents in the surrounding neighborhood; (3) jeopardize the safety of the children of the school as indicated by the independent analysis for each installation performed by Hammett & Edison, Inc.
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept such proposals as may be recommended by staff, subject to the parties executing a final lease agreement in form satisfactory to the District and that any such agreement(s) be presented to the Board for ratification at the time of the next regular Board meeting.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.06
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Business Services Division
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
E-Rate Update
	 
	 
The following summary is the current status of the district’s effort to recoup E-Rate discounts for the 2008 Funding Year in the amount of $1,156,962.   
	 
The Schools and Libraries Program of the Universal Service Fund, commonly known as "E-Rate," is administered by the Universal Service Administrative Company (USAC) under the direction of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), and provides discounts to assist schools and libraries to obtain affordable telecommunications and internet access.
	 
Concerns were raised regarding the district’s 2008 E-Rate application through a Selective Review and a whistle-blower complaint.  The whistle-blower complaint triggered a Special Compliance review of the district’s technology plan, upgrading of the phone system with VOIP and increasing the bandwidth of the Wide Area Network.  For nearly a year, communication with USAC was at a standstill.  With the assistance from Congressman Honda’s office, a line of communication was reestablished with USAC.   Through the Special Compliance review process, numerous issues were raised and answered.  One issue raised by Special Compliance review was the percentage use of cell phone for personal calls.  After the review, ESUHSD may only claim 94% of cell phone calls made. The other 6% of cell phone calls are attributed to personal use and, therefore, not allowable under E-Rate.
	 
The current issue under review is the district’s bidding procedure to acquire internet access purchased from AT&T (SBC at the time) in October / November 2005.  Whenever an E-Rate eligible service is being considered for purchase, the bidding process must start with the posting a notice called Form 470.  On October 28, 2005, a Form 470 was posted and, thus, began a 28-day waiting period for bids to come in.   In this situation, no bids were received within the time frame allowed, which resulted in ESUHSD signing a contract with AT&T for internet access services on or about November 25, 2005.  
	 
During the Special Compliance review process, an issue developed where an E-Rate reviewer noted that, by our own admission, a competing bid from Qwest Communication, in 2005, may have not been considered properly.  E-Rate regulations are clear in that when two or more bids are received, an evaluation must take place with the award winner being the most cost effective bid.   The district explained the discrepancy by noting that the Qwest bid arrived late and, therefore, not eligible for consideration.   
	 
The explanation was provided to the Special Compliance Review Unit, along with the Quest bid documentation.  In response, the Special Compliance Review Unit has requested a copy of the AT&T contract. The district has been granted an extension until February 17, 2011, to provide adequate documentation regarding its claims.

SUBJECT:
Accept Warrant Register for the Month of January 2011
	 
	 
Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of January 2011, in response to board Policy 3314 Payment for Goods and Services adopted by the board in May 2009.  The Policy states that, “The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting".  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval of issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the “transparency” of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.

EAST  SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
					 
Item 14.12
					 
					 
TO:
 Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
 Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
 June Francis Rono, Ph.D., Director of Facilities and Planning
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
 Approve Change Order #1 for Foothill High School Buildings B, C, and E Modernization Project (Beals Martin, Inc.)
					 
					 
					 
The Foothill High School Buildings B, C, and E Modernization Project is complete.  The following change order is submitted to the Board of Trustees for approval.
					 
	 
	 
Bid #
Purchase Order #
DSA #
Project #
					B-10-09-10
				003157
					01-111069
					E-005-001
	 
	 
	 
Item #
Description/Reason
Requestor
Amount
					1
					Allowance equal to 10% of the contract value was included in the bid to compensate for additions to the scope of work.  The full amount of this allowance is being credited back and all changes are listed individually herein.
					Requested by District
					($123,340.00)
					2
					Contractor's bid included an allowance for replacement of 12 plywood sheets at a unit cost of $135 per plywood sheet.  A total of five dry-rotted sheets were replaced, resulting in a net credit.
					Conditions Warranted
				($945.00)
					3
					Replace all existing windows at Buildings B, C, and E, a total of 36, at the District's request.  Contractor's bid included an allowance to replace six windows at a unit cost of $219 per window.  An additional 30 windows were replaced.
					Requested by District
					$6,570.00
					4
					An allowance for moisture treatment of the existing slab was included in the bid.  This was unused and the full amount is being credited back.
					Requested by District
					($40,000.00)
				5
				At all classroom entryways, existing exterior landing was approximately 1" below interior slab.  The elevation of the exterior landing needed to be raised in order to provide a flush condition.  This affected the interface of the slab and bottom of the plywood siding and trim.  Documents show to cut back base trim in place, however this condition required complete removal and reinstallation of trim and added caulking to provide a watertight improvement to the previous existing condition.
				Conditions Warranted
				$1,178.00
				6
				Three existing scuppers were not noted on the plans and need to be replaced.  Reference RFI 17, Bulletin #3.
				Conditions Warranted
				$1,041.00
				7
				Crickets were determined to be unnecessary by the roofing manufacturer and were deleted.
				Requested by Architect
				($1,248.00)
				8
				After demolition, it was discovered that each classroom had an outside air duct penetrating through the exterior wall which was previously concealed from view.  RFI #24 directed this vent to be cut back and patched to allow for new drywall installation.
				Conditions Warranted
				$1,907.00
				9
				At the District's request, two "teacher stations" were added in each classroom (24 total) to provide remote connectivity to the Smartboards.  This involved additional rough electrical work for additional conduit and junction boxes, additional wiring and outlets for power, and additional VGA and CAT-6 cabling, and connectors.
				Requested by District
				$33,303.00
				10
				District requested change from specified 5300 series Mechoshade fabric to fabric #6011.
				Requested by District
				$212.00
				11
				Cost for abating additional drywall beyond the amount specified in the Hazardous Materials Specification.
				Conditions Warranted
				$8,781.00
				12
				Two new access panels at each building cannot be installed in the locations shown and these access panels have been deleted with the approval of the District.  In addition, one access panel at each building shown to be new was actually existing and could be reused.  A total of nine access panels are being credited back to the District.
				Requested by District
				($1,857.00)
				13
				Existing framing for roof access doors was not up to current standards and needed to be reframed at 12 locations.
				Conditions Warranted
				$3,873.00
				14
				Demolish substandard 2 x 4 partition wall and header; replace with new 2 x 6 framed walls at two locations.
				Conditions Warranted
				$3,604.00
				15
				Detail on plans did not indicate any hardware to attach curbs for HVAC duct penetration to blocking below.  RFI #18 added A35 clips and straps to this detail, which occurs at a total of 24 locations.
				Requested by Architect
				$2,437.00
				16
				Contract documents noted to replace "E" windows with glass.  District requested they be replaced with plastic to match the existing condition.  PCO #3 covers the cost of the replacement.  This PCO represents the cost increase from glass to plastic only.
				Requested by District
				$916.00
				17
				It was determined that existing conduits called out to be used for routing new low voltage were too full to fit new cabling.  A new pull box and conduit needed to be installed on the interior side of the exterior wall of Building A in order to complete the route to the MDF room.  This involved penetrating through an asbestos containing ceiling, and at the recommendation of the District's hazardous materials consultant, a certified asbestos removal company was brought in to perform this work.
				Conditions Warranted
				$1,787.00
				18
				In order to improve the appearance of classroom entryways, recessed entry areas (6 total) were cleaned and painted.  This was not included in the original scope of work and the project team decided it would be a beneficial improvement to the project.
				Requested by District
				$1,894.00
				19
				Upon attempting to start up HVAC units in Building B, it was discovered that the existing gas regulator servicing the building was deteriorated beyond repair and needed to be replaced.  Contractor furnished and installed new regulator.
				Conditions Warranted
				$2,502.00
				20
				Demolish existing structurally unsafe storage shed.
				Requested by District
				$11,346.00
	 
	 
	 
	 
Original Contract Price
					$1,561,336.00
CREDIT TO DISTRICT
for this change order
					($86,039.00)
Revised Contract Amount
					$1,475,297.00
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
					($86,039.00)
					 
					 
FUNDING SOURCE:
					Capital Facilities Fund
					 
					 
RECOMMENDATION:
					It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order #1 for Foothill High School Buildings B, C, and E Modernization Project (Beals Martin, Inc.).
